sen.j: 奈良線（ならせん）は、京都府木津川市の木津駅 (京都府)から京都府京都市下京区の京都駅に至る西日本旅客鉄道（JR西日本）の鉄道路線（幹線）である。
sen.e: (JR) Nara Line is a railway track (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) between Kizu Station (Kyoto Prefecture) in Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture and Kyoto Station in Shimogyo Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

The (JR) Nara Line is a railway track (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) between Kizu Station (Kyoto Prefecture) in Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture, and Kyoto Station in the Shimogyo ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

The JR Nara Line is a railway line (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) that runs between Kizu Station (Kyoto Prefecture) in Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture, and Kyoto Station in the Shimogyo Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: Here we are talking about the railway line rather than the actual track itself (the Japanese says "路線" rather than "線路") so "railway line" is much more natural. Adding "that runs" makes the English read a little more smoothly.

sen.j: 全線が大都市近郊区間に含まれる。
sen.e: The whole line is included in the section of the metropolitan area and its suburbs.
The entire line is included in the section covering the metropolitan area and its suburbs.
The entire rail line is included in the section covering the metropolitan area and its suburbs.
sen.cmt: "entire line" -> "entire rail line" に変更しました。

sen.j: 関西本線の支線としての沿革を持つため、正式な起点は木津駅だが、列車運行上は京都から木津へ向かう列車が下り（列車番号は奇数）、逆が上り（同偶数）となっている。
sen.e: Since the Nara Line is historically a branch line of Kansai Main Line, an official starting station is the Kizu Station, but the outbound trains (odd-numbered trains) run from Kyoto to Kizu and the inbound trains (even-numbered trains) run the other way for train operation.

Because the Nara Line is historically a branch line of Kansai Main Line, Kizu Station is the official starting station but the outbound trains (odd-numbered trains) run from Kyoto to Kizu and the inbound trains (even-numbered trains) run the other way for train operation.

Although the Nara Line officially starts at Kizu Station because it is historically a branch line of the Kansai Main Line, outbound trains (odd-numbered trains) run from Kyoto to Kizu and inbound trains (even-numbered trains) run in the opposite direction.
sen.cmt: 下り→ outbound 上り→inboundTo the best of my knowledge as a native speaker of English "down trains" and "up trains". The term "starting station" does exist but it seems to be used to indicate the starting point of someone's journey rather than the first station on a line (I don't think we have a specific term for this in English).

sen.j: 以下路線データを除き特記なければ、京都から木津へ下り方向に記述する。
sen.e: Unless otherwise specified, the descriptions are given according to the outbound direction from Kyoto to Kizu except the Track data in the following.
Unless otherwise specified, the descriptions are given according to the outbound direction from Kyoto to Kizu, except for the track data in the following.
Unless otherwise specified, the descriptions are given according to the outbound direction from Kyoto to Kizu, except for in the track data section.
sen.cmt: The term "down train" is not used in English and "down direction" also sounds unnatural here.

sen.j: ラインカラーは茶色（■）であり、選定理由は「二本の古都を結ぶクラシックな落ち着いたイメージ」とされている。
sen.e: The Line's own color is brown (■), which is selected for "classic, sophisticated impression suitable for connections between two historic cities."
sen.cmt: 「二本」は「日本」の誤記かと思われますが、原文のまま訳しました
sen.e: The line's own color is brown (■), which has been chosen to represent "classic, sophisticated impression suitable for connections between two historic cities."

sen.j: 線路名称として京都～木津間が奈良線と名付けられているが、その全区間が京都府内にあり、奈良県内には全く路線がない。
sen.e: The line between the Kyoto Station and the Kizu Station is called the Nara Line, but the whole line lies in Kyoto Prefecture, not in Nara Prefecture.
The line between Kyoto Station and Kizu Station is called the Nara Line, but the entire line lies within Kyoto Prefecture, not in Nara Prefecture.
The line between Kyoto Station and Kizu Station is called the Nara Line, but the entire line lies within Kyoto Prefecture, not in Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: これは当初奈良鉄道によって京都～奈良間が建設されたものの、関西鉄道に合併された後に大阪～名古屋ルートの一部として木津以南を分離された、との経緯による。
sen.e: This is because, initially, the Nara Line was built by Nara Railways between the Kyoto Station and the Nara station, but the Kizu Station and other stations to the south of the Kizu Station were separated from the Nara Line to be part of a route between Osaka and Nagoya after the Nara Railways was merged into Kansai Railways.

This is because, initially, the Nara Line was built by Nara Railways between Kyoto Station and Nara Station, but Kizu Station and other stations south of Kizu Station were separated from the Nara Line in order to be part of a route between Osaka and Nagoya after Nara Railways was merged into Kansai Railways.

This is because, initially, the Nara Line was built by Nara Railways between Kyoto Station and Nara Station, but Kizu Station and other stations south of Kizu Station were separated from the Nara Line in order to be part of a route between Osaka and Nagoya after Nara Railways was merged into Kansai Railways.

sen.j: ただし、列車は木津駅から関西本線（大和路線）に入って奈良県の奈良駅まで運行される。
sen.e: Trains run from the Kizu Station to the Nara Station in Nara Prefecture through Kansai Main Line (Yamatoji Line).

However, trains run from Kizu Station to Nara Station in Nara Prefecture through the Kansai Main Line (Yamatoji Line).

sen.j: JR西日本は1988年3月13日改正でアーバンネットワークの各路線に愛称路線名（JR京都線・JR神戸線など）を定めたが、奈良線については見送られた。
sen.e: The JR West established popular names (JR Kyoto Line, JR Kobe Line or the like) for the lines in the Urban Network by the revision of March 13, 1988, but a popular name was not given to the Nara Line.
JR West established popular names (JR Kyoto Line, JR Kobe Line or the like) for the lines in the Urban Network with the revision of March 13, 1988, but a popular name was not given to the Nara Line.
JR West established popular names (JR Kyoto Line, JR Kobe Line or the like) for the lines in the Urban Network with the revision of March 13, 1988, but a popular name was not given to the Nara Line.

sen.j: 近畿日本鉄道にも近鉄奈良線があるため、「JR奈良線」と案内されることもある。
sen.e: The Nara Line is also referred to as "JR Nara Line" to be distinguished from the Kintetsu Nara Line of the Kintetsu Corporation.
The Nara Line is also referred to as the "JR Nara Line" to distinguish it from the Kintetsu Nara Line of Kintetsu Corporation.
The Nara Line is also referred to as the 'JR Nara Line' in order to distinguish it from the Kintetsu Nara Line of Kintetsu Corporation.

sen.j: 日本国有鉄道時代には「国鉄奈良線」と案内されており、案内板の英字表記も「JNR」を入れていた。
sen.e: The Nara Line used to be referred to as "JNR Nara Line" in the era of Japan National Railways (JNR), the former JR, and the information board included the English notation of "JNR".
The Nara Line was referred to as the "JNR Nara Line" in the era of Japan National Railways (JNR), the former JR, and the information board included the English notation "JNR."
The Nara Line was referred to as the 'JNR Nara Line' in the era of Japan National Railways (JNR), the former JR, and the information board included the English notation 'JNR.'

sen.j: 近鉄奈良線は難波～奈良で大和路線と対抗関係にあり、JR奈良線が対抗関係にあるのは近鉄京都線である。
sen.e: The Kintetsu Nara Line is competitive to the Yamatoji Line between Namba and Nara, whereas the JR Nara Line is competitive to the Kintetsu Kyoto Line.
The Kintetsu Nara Line competes with the Yamatoji Line between Namba and Nara, whereas the JR Nara Line competes with the Kintetsu Kyoto Line.
The Kintetsu Nara Line competes with the Yamatoji Line between Nanba and Nara, whereas the JR Nara Line competes with the Kintetsu Kyoto Line.

sen.j: 並行する京阪宇治線や近鉄京都線は以前から多数の列車が運行されていたのに対し、奈良線は国鉄末期の1984年まで鉄道の電化がされず、電化後も国鉄民営化までのしばらくは国鉄105系電車の2両編成などが細々と走る小さなローカル線でしかなかった。
sen.e: Many trains used to travel on Keihan Uji Line or Kintetsu Kyoto Line lying parallel to the Nara Line, whereas the Nara Line was electrified only after 1984 in the end of JNR, and was just a small local line on which JNR/JR Commuter Trains Series 105 comprising two vehicles or the like ran for some time even after the electrification until the privatization of the JNR.

Many trains used to travel on the Keihan Uji Line or the Kintetsu Kyoto Line lying parallel to the Nara Line, whereas the Nara Line was electrified only after 1984 at the end of JNR, and was just a small local line on which JNR/JR Commuter Train Series 105 (comprising two vehicles or the like) ran for some time, even after electrification until the privatization of the JNR.

While many trains used to run on the Keihan Uji Line and the Kintetsu Kyoto Line (both of which run parallel to the Nara Line), the Nara Line was only electrified toward the end of JNR in 1984; consequently, it remained just a small local line on which the JNR/JR Commuter Train Series 105 (comprising two cars or the like) ran for some time, even after electrification, until the privatization of the JNR.
sen.cmt: I'm afraid "until the privatization of the JNR even after electrification" doesn't really make any sense in English so I have reversed the order.

sen.j: しかし、JR西日本が発足して以降にアーバンネットワークの中に当線を組み込んでからは、列車の4両編成化（一部は6両編成）、部分複線化、「みやこ路快速」などの快速列車を始めとする列車の増発など、急速に輸送改善が図られた。
sen.e: However, after the foundation of the JR West and the Nara Line being incorporated into the Urban Network, the improvement of transportation services was rapidly made by, for example, trains composed of four vehicles (some composed of six vehicles), double track in part, or increase in the number of trains including rapid trains such as "Miyakoji rapid train."

However, after the foundation of the JR West and the Nara Line's incorporation into the Urban Network, the improvement of transportation services was rapidly made by, for example, trains comprised of four vehicles (some comprised of six vehicles), double-tracked in part, or with increased numbers of trains, including rapid trains such as "Miyakoji rapid train."

However, after the foundation of JR West and the Nara Line's incorporation into the Urban Network, the improvement of transportation services was quickly achieved with, for example, trains comprised of four cars (some comprised of six cars), double-tracked in part, or with increased numbers of trains, including rapid services such as the 'Miyakoji Rapid Service.'

sen.j: 現在では、沿線にある宇治市の平等院などへの観光や、城陽市など京都府南部地域からの通勤・通学路線としての性格が強くなっている。
sen.e: Today, the Nara Line is characterized by the access to sightseeing areas such as Byodo-in Temple in Uji City or by a commuter line for passengers from the south part of the Kyoto Prefecture such as Joyo City.

sen.j: しかし桃山～新田間で東側に大きく迂回する形となっており、城陽以南は町の中心部の外れを走るので並行する近鉄京都線とは京奈間・地域輸送共にまだ格差がある。
sen.e: However, trains go around toward east between the Momoyama Station and the Shinden Station and run the edge of the central part of towns in Joyo or to the south of Joyo, and thus, the regional and the transportation gaps between the Nara Line and the Kintetsu Kyoto Line still remain.

sen.cmt: I have added "commuter passes" because otherwise someone not familiar with Japan might have trouble understanding what these are.Reference for Surutto Kansai Association: http://www.surutto.com/conts/ticket/3dayeng/index.html

sen.j: 1984年に京都～和歌山駅間を奈良線・桜井線・和歌山線経由で結んでいた急行列車「くろしお_(列車)」が廃止されて以来、1991年までは普通列車のみの運転だった（特急のように、一時期臨時で特別急行列車が運転されたことがある）が、今ではみやこ路快速、快速列車、列車種別区間種別、普通列車の4種類の種別が運転されている。
sen.e: After Limited Express "Kuroshio" connecting the Kyoto Station with the Wakayama Station via the Nara Line, Sakurai Line, and Wakayama Line stopped its operation in 1984, only the local trains ran until 1991 (except that the special limited express was temporarily operated), but now there are four types of trains: the Miyakoji rapid train, the rapid train, the trains classified by operation and section, and the local train.
sen.cmt: 「列車種別区間種別」については、「運行および区間によって分類された列車」と解し訳しました。

Before March 2001, when the "Miyakoji rapid train" began operating, the rapid train had stopped at the Kyoto, Uji, Joyo (except at the beginning), Kizu and Nara stations and employed JNR/JR Suburban Train Series 117 for its vehicle; however, the JNR/JR Suburban Train Series 117 has not been used on the Nara Line since March 2001.

Before the 'Miyakoji rapid train' came into operation in March 2001, the rapid train had stopped at Kyoto, Uji, Joyo (except at the beginning), Kizu and Nara stations, employing the JNR/JR Suburban Train Series 117 for its cars; since then, however, this series has not been used on the Nara Line.

sen.e: The section rapid stops at every station between the Uji Station and the Nara Station; some section rapids bound for Kizu used to pass the local train at the Uji Station in the late evening etc. due to the schedule; but now the section rapid does not pass the local train before reaching the arrival station according to the current schedule.

The rapid section stops at every station between Uji Station and Nara Station; some rapid sections bound for Kizu used to pass the local train at the Uji Station in the late evening, etc., due to the schedule, but based on the current schedule the rapid section does not pass the local train before reaching the arrival station.

The regional rapid service stops at every station between Uji Station and Nara Station, while some regional rapid services bound for Kizu used to pass the local train at Uji Station in the late evening, etc., due to the schedule; however, based on the current schedule, the regional rapid service doesn't pass the local train before reaching the arrival station.

sen.e: The section rapid on the Nara Line used to use orange letters as the Line's own color, which was the same color as the one used for the "Miyakoji rapid train" and the rapid train, so as to distinguish the section rapid on the Nara Line from that on the Yamatoji Line, but in March 2008, by the replacement of signs along with the revision of the schedule, a sign for the section rapid was changed to include green letters, thereby the use of Line color was stopped.

The rapid section on the Nara Line used to use orange letters as the line's own color, but it was the same color as the one used for the "Miyakoji rapid train" and the rapid train so as to distinguish the rapid section on the Nara Line from that on the Yamatoji Line. However, in March 2008, with the replacement of signs along with the revision of the schedule, a sign for the rapid section was changed to include green letters, whereby the use of the line color was stopped.

The regional rapid service on the Nara Line formerly used orange letters as the Line's own color, but it was the same color as the one used for the 'Miyakoji Rapid Service' and the rapid service so as to distinguish the regional rapid service on the Nara Line from that of the Yamatoji Line. However, in March 2008, with the replacement of signs along with the revision of the schedule, a sign for the regional rapid service was changed to include green letters, whereby the use of the line color was stopped.

sen.j: 東海道本線の馬場（現在の膳所）～京都間が東山トンネル経由の現在線に切り替えられた1921年のその日に、京都～稲荷間の旧東海道本線と稲荷～桃山間の新線が奈良線となり、京都～伏見間が廃止、伏見～桃山間が貨物線化された。
sen.e: In 1921, the Tokaido Main Line between the Baba (currently Zeze) Station and the Kyoto Station was switched to the current line via the Higashiyama tunnel, and on the same day, the old Tokaido Main Line between the Kyoto Station and the Inari Station and a new line between the Inari Station and the Momoyama Station came to serve as the Nara Line, thereby abolishing the line between the Kyoto Station and the Fushimi Station and making the line between the Fushimi Station and the Momoyama Station a freight line.

In 1921, the Tokaido Main Line between Baba (currently Zeze) Station and Kyoto Station was switched to the current line via the Higashiyama tunnel; and on the same day the old Tokaido Main Line between Kyoto Station and Inari Station and a new line between Inari Station and Momoyama Station came to serve as the Nara Line, whereby the line between Kyoto Station and Fushimi Station was abolished and the line between Fushimi Station and Momoyama Station was made a freight line.

In 1921, the Tokaido Main Line between Baba (currently Zeze) Station and Kyoto Station was switched to the current line via the Higashiyama tunnel; and on the same day the old Tokaido Main Line between Kyoto Station and Inari Station and a new line between Inari Station and Momoyama Station came to serve as the Nara Line, whereby the line between Kyoto Station and Fushimi Station was abolished and the line between Fushimi Station and Momoyama Station was made a freight line.

sen.e: The single track sections between JR-Fujinomori Station and the Uji Station and between the Shinden Station and the Kizu Station still remain under discussion, but no specific plan has been given.

sen.j: また、JR藤森駅～桃山駅間の国道24号線沿いや木幡駅～宇治駅間（黄檗駅付近）の京阪宇治線沿いは特に用地買収確保が難しい区間である。
sen.e: Additionally, the acquisition of the lands along the National Highway 24 between the JR-Fujinomori Station and the Momoyama Station, and along the Keihan Uji Line between the Kohata Station and the Uji Station (near the Obaku Station) is particularly difficult.

sen.e: In the Council for Transportation in Kinki region, a plan for operating the Nara Line through to the Tokaido Main Line (the JR Kyoto Line) in the feature is under discussion (there was once an overnight service from the late-evening on December 31 to the early morning on January 1).
